Package algorithms.misc

Class MiscMath0

java.lang.Object
algorithms.misc.MiscMath0
public class MiscMath0 extends Object
miscellaneous math methods. some could probably be improved. first implemented in projects https://github.com/nking/two-point-correlation w/ Copyright (c) 2013-2015 Nichole King http://nking.github.io/two-point-correlation/ using The MIT License (MIT) and https://github.com/nking/curvature-scale-space-corners-and-transformations w/ Copyright (c) 2014 Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license.
Author:
nichole

    • roundUpByLargestPower

      public static float roundUpByLargestPower(float f)
      Round number up to the next digit in the largest power. MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(31.1f) == 40.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(0.11f) == 1.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(-0.011f) == -0.02f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(310.1f) == 400.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(-3.1) == -4.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(3.1) == 4.0f;
      Parameters:
      f -
      Returns:

    • roundDownByLargestPower

      public static float roundDownByLargestPower(float f)
      Round number down to in the largest power. For example, roundDownByLargestPower(3.1) returns 3.0 roundDownByLargestPower(-3.1) returns -4.0 roundDownByLargestPower(31.1) returns 30.0
      Parameters:
      f -
      Returns:

    • findStrongPeakIndexes

      public static List<Integer> findStrongPeakIndexes(HistogramHolder h, float frac)
      for the given histogram, returns the indexes of the primary peak and any peaks which are larger than frac*maxPeak above their neighboring values.
      Parameters:
      h -
      frac - the fraction of the y value of the maximum peak that is used as a critical limit that any other peaks must have in excess of their neighboring points. For example, 0.1.
      Returns:

    • calculateQuartiles

      public static double[] calculateQuartiles(double[] x)
      calculate the quartiles Q1, Q2, and Q3 of x as 
       x = ascending sort(x)
 n = x.length;
 Q1 = median of x[0] through x[n/2] which is x[n/4];
 Q2 = median of x = x[n/2];
 Q3 = median of x[n/2] through x[n-1] = x[(int)0.75*n];
      The IQR is Q3 - Q1;
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:
      an array holding Q1, Q2, Q3, min and max

    • findInliersUsingTukeyFences

      public static int[] findInliersUsingTukeyFences(double[] x)
      uses Tukey fences to find inlier indexes in x with factor k=1.5 
          calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:

    • findFarInliersUsingTukeyFences

      public static int[] findFarInliersUsingTukeyFences(double[] x)

          calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:

    • findInliersUsingTukeyFences

      public static int[] findInliersUsingTukeyFences(double[] x, double k)
      uses Tukey fences to find inlier indexes in x. 
          calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
      Parameters:
      x -
      k -
      Returns:

    • calculateMedianOfAbsoluteDeviation

      public static double[] calculateMedianOfAbsoluteDeviation(double[] x)
      calculate the median of absolute deviation (MAD) as 
        absDev_i = abs(x_i - median(x))
        mad = median( absDev)
      and returns [median of absolute deviation, median, min, max]. To use the MAD as one uses standard deviation in determining outliers, use stDev = k*MAD where k is a constant scale factor. For gaussian k~1.4826. Outliers are outside the range [median - 3*k*MAD, median + 3*k*MAD].
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:
      an array holding the median of absolute deviation of x, the median, the min, and the max.

           https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartile
     Method 1
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:
      min, Q1, Q2, Q3, max

    • calcMeanAndSSD

      public static double[] calcMeanAndSSD(double[] x)
      calculate the mean of x and the sum of the squared differences (SSD) between x and the mean. The SSD can be used to calculate the biased or unbiased variance, standard deviation, and standard error. 
           mean = (1/n)*sum_{i=0 to n-1}(x_i) where n = x.length

     SSD = sum_{i=0 to n-1}((x_i - mean)^2)

     sample standard deviation:
         n-1 degrees of freedom within a sample of size n for having
         to estimate the mean from data,
         is a.k.a. unbiased standard deviation.
         note that standard deviation is not appropriate for all
         distributions, e.g. categorical.
     = sqrt( SSD / (n-1) )

     population standard deviation:
         true population mean is known, so n degrees of freedom
         within a sample of size n
     = sqrt( SSD/ n) biased, population mean is known

     standard error (SE):
         the standard deviation of the mean itself, across more
         than one sample.
         used in confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.
         e.g. 95% - confidence interval = mean += 1.96 * SE for
         gaussian normal distribution
         assumptions of same sample size and drawn from same population.
     = sample standard deviation / sqrt(n)
     = sqrt( SSD / (n*(n-1)) )
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:
      array of length 2 holding the mean of x and the ssum of the square differences of x from the mean.

    • calcMeanAndSSD

      public static double[] calcMeanAndSSD(int[] x)
      calculate the mean of x and the sum of the squared differences (SSD) between x and the mean. The SSD can be used to calculate the biased or unbiased variance, standard deviation, and standard error. 
           mean = (1/n)*sum_{i=0 to n-1}(x_i) where n = x.length

     SSD = sum_{i=0 to n-1}((x_i - mean)^2)

     sample standard deviation:
         n-1 degrees of freedom within a sample of size n for having
         to estimate the mean from data,
         is a.k.a. unbiased standard deviation.
         note that standard deviation is not appropriate for all
         distributions, e.g. categorical.
     = sqrt( SSD / (n-1) )

     population standard deviation:
         true population mean is known, so n degrees of freedom
         within a sample of size n
     = sqrt( SSD/ n) biased, population mean is known

     standard error (SE):
         the standard deviation of the mean itself, across more
         than one sample.
         used in confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.
         e.g. 95% - confidence interval = mean += 1.96 * SE for
         gaussian normal distribution
         assumptions of same sample size and drawn from same population.
     = sample standard deviation / sqrt(n)
     = sqrt( SSD / (n*(n-1)) )
      Parameters:
      x -
      Returns:
      array of length 2 holding the mean of x and the ssum of the square differences of x from the mean.

    • calcMean

      public static double calcMean(double[] x)
      calculate the arithmetic mean of x 
           arithetic mean: (1/n)*sum(x_i) for i = 0 to n-1 where n = x.length
      Parameters:
      x - array of values
      Returns:
      arithmetic mean of x

    • calcGeometricMean

      public static double calcGeometricMean(double[] x)
      calculate the geometric mean of array x. 
           geometric mean: (product(x_i))^(1/n) for i=0 to n-1 where n=x.length.
      Note that to handle potentially very small and very large numbers, the logarithm is used followed by exponential of the result. (logarithm transforms the product into sum, making it the arithmetic mean).
      Parameters:
      x - array of values. note that a 0 in x results in a geometric mean of 0
      Returns:
      geometric mean of x

    • calcHarmonicMean

      public static double calcHarmonicMean(double[] x)
      calculate the harmonic mean of array x. 
           harmonic mean: n/(sum(1/a_i)) for i=0 to n-1 where n = x.length
      Parameters:
      x - array of values. note that any 0 in x will throw a divide by zero runtime error.
      Returns:
      harmonic mean

    • numberOfSetBits

      public static int numberOfSetBits(long x)

           reference:
     https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_weight
     method popcount64c
      Parameters:
      x - the bitstring with the set bits to count
      Returns:
      the number of bits set in x

    • logspace

      public static gnu.trove.list.array.TDoubleArrayList logspace(float start, float stop, int num, boolean endpoint)
      method from scipy's numpy package to return numbers spaced evenly on a log scale. 
           numpy is licensed under BSD 3-clause "New" or "Revised" License
      
     https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
      Parameters:
      start - is the starting value of the sequence.
      stop - float is the final value of the sequence, unless `endpoint` is False. In that case, ``num + 1`` values are spaced over the interval in log-space, of which all but the last (a sequence of length ``num``) are returned.
      num - : Number of samples to generate. Default is 50.
      endpoint - : If true, `stop` is the last sample. Otherwise, it is not included. Default is True.
      Returns:

    • linspace

      public static gnu.trove.list.array.TFloatArrayList linspace(float start, float stop, int num, boolean endpoint)
      adapted method from scipy's numpy package to return evenly spaced numbers over a specified interval 
           numpy is licensed under BSD 3-clause "New" or "Revised" License
      
     https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
      Parameters:
      start - is the starting value of the sequence.
      stop - float is the final value of the sequence, unless `endpoint` is False. In that case, ``num + 1`` values are spaced over the interval in log-space, of which all but the last (a sequence of length ``num``) are returned.
      num - : Number of samples to generate. Default is 50.
      endpoint - : If true, `stop` is the last sample. Otherwise, it is not included. Default is True.
      Returns:

    • mean

      public static double[] mean(double[] data, int nDimensions)
      calculates the mean of the data per dimension and returns it as a point in all dimensions.
      Parameters:
      data - nDimensional data points in format [ point_0 in all dimensions, point_1 in all dimensions, ... point_{n-1} in all dimensions[
      nDimensions - the number of dimensions of a point
      Returns:
      an array holding the mean per dimension, e.g. point_0_0, point_0_1, point_0_2...point_0_{nDimensions-1}]

      public static double[][] standardDeviation(double[] data, int nDimensions)

    • computeNDivKTimesNMinusK

      public static long computeNDivKTimesNMinusK(int n, int k)
      compute n!/k!(n-k)!. if the result is larger than Long.MAX_VALUE the method throws an ArithmeticException. runtime complexity is O(k) (Aho and Ullman "Foundations of Computer Science")
      Parameters:
      n -
      k -
      Returns:
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - thrown when result is out of range of type long

    • calcSampleSkewness

      public static double calcSampleSkewness(double[] data)
      third standardized moment of skewness as sample skewness: 
        https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skewness
     g1 = kappa_3/((kappa_2)^(3/2))
        = (1/n) * summation from i=1 to n ( (x_i - mean)^3)
           / ([ (1/n) * summation from i=1 to n ( (x_i - mean)^2) ]^(3/2) )

           where kappa_2 is the 2nd cumulant = variance.
          kappa_3 = central moment which is skewness
      Parameters:
      data -
      Returns:

    • eulerMascheroniConstant

      public static double eulerMascheroniConstant()
      return the Euler-Mascheroni constant. It is the first derivative of the gamma function w.r.t. n at n=1.

    • areColinear

      public static boolean areColinear(double[][] X, double tol)
      determine whether any 3 points in X are colinear. note that the method has not been edited for large number of points in X yet.
      Parameters:
      X - data points in format [2 X nPoints] or [3 X nPoints] where row 0 are the 'x dimension' points, and row 1 are the 'y dimension' points. if row 2 is present, it is ignored as it is expected to be the z-axis of homogenous points (= value 1) and hence is not used.
      tol -
      Returns:

    • multiDimensionToSingleIndex

      public static int multiDimensionToSingleIndex(int[] indexes, int[] dimensionWidths)
      convert multiple indexes of a the given dimensions to a single index. e.g. given indexes = 1,4 as x,y and dimensions=10,11 as width,height returns indexes[1]*dimensions[0] + indexes[0] = 4*10 + 1 = 41
      Parameters:
      indexes -
      dimensionWidths -
      Returns:
      a single indexes composed of a decomposable result of multiples and additions of indexes and dimensions.

    • singleIndexToMultiDimension

      public static void singleIndexToMultiDimension(int index, int[] dimensionWidths, int[] outIndexes)
      given an index created with multiDimensionToSingleIndex(...), decompose it into the individual indexes for each dimension. e.g., given idx=41, and dimensions=10,11 as width,height, returns outIndexes[0] = idx % dimensionWidths[0]=1 and outIndexes[1] = idx / dimensionWidths[0]=4
      Parameters:
      index -
      dimensionWidths -
      outIndexes -
